i believe tha "committee machines" are another approach to using multiple 
networks. its an attempt to solve the bias vs variance problem, where you 
might have a simple network model that will offer about the same 
performance (no matter how poor) on any particular data sample you give 
it (i.e., a low variance from sample to sample, but a high bias from the 
actual data), as opposed to a complex 
model that will fit one particular data sample 
perfectly but will be poor at other samples (low bias, but high variance).

with a committee you have a group of networks that all train separately 
(with potentially different combinations of the input data, from cross 
corrollation or something similar) and then combine the results together. 
from what i've heard, it works pretty well on classification tasks.

i'm sure pretty much anyone on here would know more about this than i do, 
but we talked about it in lecture today so i wanted to throw in my 2 
cents. or i suppose it should be my 2 pence since i'm currently studying 
in england (although with the exchange rate .... 2 cents is barely 1 
pence. *sigh*)

-KB-


On Tue, 23 Mar 2004, Ian Badcoe wrote:

> Hi,
> 	I'm a newby here but I've been lurking a few weeks.
> 
> 	This multiple networks topic is pretty much at the heart of my 
> interests.  I'm not coming only from an ANN angle, but I'm very interested 
> in approaches for combining multiple entities of any evolving/learning type 
> (ANN, GP, GA, ...) into coherent wholes.
> 
> 	It's a complex area and not hugely reported in the existing literature.
> 
> 	I've found two existing approaches exist:
> 
> 1) those variations on the "classifier system" approach which use the 
> output form the whole population.  Typically this seems to be achieved by 
> letting the fittest individual process all those cases it can before 
> passing any remaining cases to the next fittest.  Obviously for 
> classification you can do this because the discrete "cases" are separate 
> and can be seen to be handled or not.  This is harder to apply to other 
> scenarios (hence your need for "confidence").  It's also necessary to be 
> able to assess an individual in the absence of the others, which also may 
> not apply for a complex situation.
> 
> 2) The "Hayek" approach of Eric Baum 
> (http://www.whatisthought.com/eric.html).  This uses economics to control 
> the confidence in each individual.  Individuals in each tick, analyse the 
> situation and bid an amount of money to be the dominant controller (Eric 
> phrases this "bidding to own the world").  The winner pays its bid to the 
> previous successful bidder ("buying the world form the previous owner", 
> which may be itself) and then takes control for one tick.  Any improvement 
> in the value of the world after the individual's actions are credited to 
> it, as well as the money from the individual buying control in the next tick.
> 
> This system works because it forces individuals to evolve an accurate 
> measure of their own confidence.  Any individual which overbids will make a 
> loss, go bankrupt and be killed.  Any which underbids will never get 
> control, make no profit, and the systems often include a fixed or 
> size-related "tax" which in time bankrupts these individuals as well.
> 
> --
> 
> I'm cautiously keen on the Hayek approach, although it has at least one 
> pretty serious weakness: in a generation, a mutant high-bidding individual 
> can grab control and deflect the whole system from profitability (say by 
> ramming a boulder head-on).  Existing Hayek implementations handle this 
> because any runs in which the system as a whole is unprofitable are taken 
> back and the offending individual eliminated (or to put it another way, 
> deals involving individuals who "default" on their bids are unwound back to 
> a previous state).  This is a fine strategy as long as the world 
> (simulation) the system lives in is cheap (because it has to be unwound as 
> well) but impractical for (i) complex simulations, (ii) simulations 
> inhabited by more than one Hayek system, or (iii) physically implemented 
> worlds (like real motorbikes in real deserts, for example).
> 
> But you can easily imagine using Hayek in this situation, feeding money 
> into the system for either forwards motion or reaching the end (either has 
> been seen to work).  Giving each ANN an output for bid (confidence) in 
> addition to its control outputs.  And there would be no concerns with using 
> several different types of ANN in the population...
> 
> 	Ian Badcoe
>
